title: Canvassing Field Report - North Swanage Door-to-Door
content:
This is James Morrison, recording field notes from today's canvassing session in North Swanage. I'm with volunteers Emma Watson and Tom Bradley.

Started at Newton Road at 2pm. First house, number 42, spoke with Mrs. Patricia Welling, elderly resident, very concerned about emergency vehicle access if Shore Road closes. She mentioned her husband had a heart attack last year and the ambulance came via Shore Road. Strong supporter, will definitely vote for Phillippe.

Number 44 no answer.

Number 46, Mr. and Mrs. Patel, own the corner shop on Redcliffe Road. Already aware of our campaign through Alice Chen and the Business Association. They're worried about delivery trucks having to take longer routes. Confirmed supporters.

Moved to Redcliffe Road. Notable interaction at number 15 - young family, the Johnsons. They just moved here from London. Not aware of the Shore Road issue at all. Emma did a great job explaining. They were shocked about the survey manipulation. The husband, Robert Johnson, works in IT and was particularly outraged about the CAPTCHA issue. He said he'd be happy to provide technical analysis if needed. Took his contact details.

Tom Bradley: Can I add something? At number 19, we met Colin Fletcher. He said he's a retired council employee and knows Gary Suttle personally. He confirmed that many council staff are privately opposed to the closure but afraid to speak up because of David Hollister's influence.

James Morrison: Good point, Tom. Yes, Mr. Fletcher at number 19 Redcliffe Road. He also mentioned that there's a WhatsApp group among council employees where they share concerns. He wouldn't give us access but said the sentiment is definitely shifting our way.

Continuing down Redcliffe Road. Number 23, hostile reception. The resident, who didn't give his name, said he supports David Hollister and slammed the door. Emma noted he had a 'Swanage News' sticker in his window.

Number 25, Mrs. Evelyn Chang, another elderly resident. She tried to complete the online survey but couldn't get past the CAPTCHA. She's furious about it. Definite supporter.

Tom Bradley: We should note that house at number 27 - big 'Vote Phillippe Edes' sign in the garden. The owner, Marcus Thompson, came out and offered us tea. He's been spreading the word among his bowling club.

James Morrison: Right, Marcus Thompson, very enthusiastic supporter. He mentioned the bowling club has about 60 members, mostly retirees who are concerned about the closure.

We then moved to Prospect Road, which runs parallel to Shore Road. This is where we hit gold. Number 8 Prospect Road, Dr. Jennifer Hart. She's a GP at the local surgery and has major concerns about patient access if Shore Road closes. She said she'd be willing to write a formal medical opinion about the health impacts. Emma's getting her full contact details.

Emma Watson: Yes, I've got Dr. Hart's email. She also mentioned that the surgery's patient transport service relies heavily on Shore Road.

James Morrison: Continuing on Prospect Road. Several no-answers, but at number 16 we met Brian Fitzgerald, who turns out to be a cousin of Tony Powell from DCF. Very awkward conversation. He defended the consultation process but couldn't explain the CAPTCHA issue. Not hostile, but definitely not a supporter.

Final street for today was Church Lane. Notable interaction at number 5, Sarah Mitchell, a teacher at Swanage Primary. She's been discussing the democratic process with her students and using our campaign as a positive example of civic engagement. She wants to bring her year 6 class to see Phillippe speak if we arrange any public events.

Tom Bradley: Don't forget the incident at number 11 Church Lane.

James Morrison: Ah yes, we encountered Mike Harrison at number 11. He claimed to be a journalist with Swanage News and started filming us without permission. I politely asked him to stop and informed him we were conducting lawful political canvassing. He became aggressive and threatened to 'expose' our 'harassment' of residents. We left immediately and I'm documenting this interaction for Barry.

Emma Watson: I got a photo of him filming us, for evidence.

James Morrison: Good thinking, Emma. Overall summary: Canvassed 24 houses, made contact with 18 residents. 14 confirmed supporters, 2 undecided but leaning our way, 1 hostile, 1 opposition journalist encounter. 

Key findings: The medical access angle with Dr. Hart is very powerful. The IT expertise from Robert Johnson could help us analyze the survey data. Colin Fletcher's inside knowledge about council staff sentiment is valuable.

Areas of concern: Mike Harrison from Swanage News is clearly trying to create negative stories about us. We need to brief all canvassers about potential media ambushes.

Next steps: I'll compile all contact details and pass to Barry. Dr. Hart's medical opinion could be crucial for the final push. The WhatsApp group Colin Fletcher mentioned warrants further investigation.

Tom Bradley: Should I write up the Marcus Thompson bowling club connection? 60 potential voters is significant.

James Morrison: Absolutely, Tom. Let's get that to Barry ASAP. Alright, ending field notes. Time is 4:47 PM. Successful session despite the Harrison incident. The momentum is definitely with us.

tasks.name: Get medical opinion from Dr. Hart

evidence.description: Mike Harrison filming canvassers without permission

location_extraction: Multiple street names with house numbers
informal_speech_parsing: Field note style vs formal transcript
